title: Does random mean that there is no pattern? - Quora

response.answer_text: No; in fact, the whole of probability may be described as trying to identify the underlying pattern in random values. Roughly speaking, when a mathematician says something is random, they mean that it is effectively unpredictable. Thus, whether a coin lands “heads” or “tails” is completely determined by the laws of physics…but in practice, we can’t measure the relevant factors accurately enough (and quickly enough) to predict the outcome. This highlights another important fact: mathematically, random does not mean reasonless. There is a reason why the coin landed heads; what makes it random is the unpredictability of how it’s going to land. Now here’s the punchline…because random means unpredictable and not reasonless, the laws of probability apply to human behavior. Thus, the outcome of elections is random, because we cannot predict what will happen. (And think about it: There are countries where election outcomes are not random…because the winner was already decided by the Central Committee. In a democracy, the outcome of an election is random, and we want it to be random) The role of probability is quantifying that randomness (it’s what Nate Silver is known for doing).

Not at all, lots of people are precisely trying to find patterns in phenomena that are (at least partially) random.  So what is random? It means that repeating the exact same process that led to the random value/phenomenon won't always give the same answer. An example maybe? I'm taking the tramway every morning, without checking when it is supposed to come, but I know one comes every ten minutes. Let's assume I have a decent transport system and that there are no late arrivals. My waiting time will be random (because I repeat the same experiment every morning, getting to the tram stop and wait for the next one) but my waiting time varies. Does is mean that there are no patterns? Nope, there is a specific distribution here: my waiting time is limited to the [0,5] interval. You could call that a pattern. Another one with a more compelling pattern: size of people vs their weight. There is obviously a pattern here (more height on average means more weight too). But is it random? Pick a bunch of people with the same height, they won't all have the same weight, so even with the same experimental conditions (picking people with a given height), weight varies a lot. Therefore you're looking at a random phenomenon, but with a clear pattern.
